p: Nong Ye is a Professor of Industrial Engineering, and an Affiliated Professor of Computer Science and Engineering at Arizona State University. She holds a Ph.D. degree in Industrial Engineering from Purdue University, a M.S. degree in Computer Science from the Chinese Academy of Sciences, and a B.S. degree in Computer Science from Peking University. Her research interests are in assuring process quality, and preventing faults and errors in information systems. Dr. Ye is an Associate Editor for IEEE Transactions on Reliability and IEEE Transactions on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics. She is a senior member of the Institute of Industrial Engineers and a senior member of IEEE.

p: Connie M. Borror is a Senior Lecturer in the Department of Industrial Engineering at Arizona State University. She received her Doctorate in Industrial Engineering from Arizona State University with an emphasis in Quality Engineering. Her research interests include new developments in statistical process control, design of experiments, and response surface methodology. She is a member of the American Society for Quality, the American Statistical Association, the Royal Statistical Society, the Institute of Industrial Engineers, the Caucus for Women in Statistics, and the American Society for Engineering Education.

details.abstract: Intrusions into computer systems have caused many quality/reliability problems. Detecting intrusions is an important part of assuring the quality/reliability of computer systems by quickly detecting intrusions and associated quality/reliability problems in order to take corrective actions. In this paper, we present and compare two methods of forecasting normal activities in computer systems for intrusion detection. One forecasting method uses the average of long-term normal activities as the forecast. Another forecasting method uses the EWMA (exponentially weighted moving average) one-step-ahead forecast. We use a Markov chain model to learn and predict normal activities used in the EWMA forecasting method. A forecast of normal activities is used to detect a large deviation of the observed activities from the forecast as a possible intrusion into computer systems. A Chi square distance metric is used to measure the deviation of the observed activities from the forecast of normal activities. The two forecasting methods are tested on computer audit data of normal and intrusive activities for intrusion detection. The results indicate that the Chi square distance measure with the EWMA forecasting provides better performance in intrusion detection than that with the average-based forecasting method.

patentCitations.title: METHOD TO INDENTIFY ANOMALOUS DATA USING CASCADED K MEANS CLUSTERING AND AN ID3 DECISION TREE
patentCitations.patentAbstract: The invention is a computer implemented technique for id entifying anomalous data in a data set. The method uses cascaded k-Means clustering and the ID3 decision tree learning methods to characterize a training data set having data points with known characterization. The k-Means clustering method first partitions the training instances into k clusters using Euclidean distance similarity. On each training cluster, representing a density region of normal or anomaly instances, the invention builds an ID3 decision tree. The decision tree on each cluster refines the decision boundaries by learning the sub-groups within the cluster. A test data point is then subjected to the clustering and decision trees constructed form the training instances. To obtain a final decision on classification, the decisions of the k-Means and ID3 methods are combined using rules: (1) the Nearest-neighbor rule, and (2) the Nearest-consensus rule.

context.text:
Detecting intrusions is an important part of assuring quality and reliability of computer systems by quickly detecting intrusions, and associated quality and reliability problems in order to take corrective actions [1]–
[4].
Intrusion detection generally takes one of two approaches: anomaly detection, and signature recognition [3]–[4][44].

For example, intrusion signature patterns have been represented as strings, event sequences, activity graphs, finite state machines, colored Petri nets, association rules, and production rules of expert systems [4], [9]–[12], [16], [17], [22]–
[24], [29].
Further details and discussions of signature recognition techniques can be found in [4], [11], [12], [40].

For example, strings, logic-based specifications, statistical distributions, statistical and fuzzy clusters, event transition probabilities, stochastic models, artificial neural networks, and association rules have been used to represent the norm profile [4]–[8], [11], [12], [18]–[21], [25], [26], [28], [30] [31]–[44].
Further details and discussions of anomaly detection techniques can be found in [4], [11], [12], [40].

A number of studies [4] [5] [6], [33], [34] on anomaly detection techniques use a norm profile for predicting a certain attribute of computer activities, and comparing the prediction with the observation to detect a large deviation from the norm profile.

In our previous work [4] [5] [6] on prediction-based anomaly detection for intrusion detection, we develop an anomaly detection method which builds the norm profile by averaging long-term normal activities in computer systems, and uses a Chi square distance measure to compute the deviation of the observed activities from the norm profile for detecting intrusions.

This method demonstrates promising performance in intrusion detection [4]–
[6].
We experience those problems when we apply this traditional distance measure to computer audit data for intrusion detection [4]–[6].

To overcome those problems, we develop a more scalable distance measure of an observation, \${\mbi X} _{\mbi i}\$, from \${\overline {\mbi X}}\$ as follows [4]–[6]:where the numerator gives the squared Euclidean distance, which is then scaled by \$\overline {X_{i,k}}\$.
Studies [4]–[6] have shown that the information of event type can be used to effectively detect intrusions.
As in our previous work [4] [5] [6], we monitor a frequency distribution of event types in the recent past of the current event for intrusion detection.
In this study, \$\eta \$ is set to 0.3 as in our previous work [4] [5] [6], which is also a common value for this parameter [46].

The intrusion detection methods presented in this paper are evaluated using ROC charts which were originally developed in the field of signal detection, and have widely been used in the field of intrusion detection [4]–
[6].

This is the best detection performance that we have obtained for the DARPA-LL 2000 data using various intrusion detection methods in our studies [4]–
[6].
In [4], we discuss several features of event sequence which have been extracted for intrusion detection in existing work on anomaly detection methods.

context.text: Intrusion detection generally takes one of two approaches: anomaly detection, and signature recognition [3]–[33][44].

For example, strings, logic-based specifications, statistical distributions, statistical and fuzzy clusters, event transition probabilities, stochastic models, artificial neural networks, and association rules have been used to represent the norm profile [4]–[8], [11], [12], [18]–[21], [25], [26], [28], [30] [31]–[33][44].

A number of studies [4] [5] [6], [33], [34] on anomaly detection techniques use a norm profile for predicting a certain attribute of computer activities, and comparing the prediction with the observation to detect a large deviation from the norm profile.

For example, studies in [33], [34] use artificial neural networks to learn a norm profile of event sequences, use the norm profile to predict the next event given its previous events, and compare the predicted event with the observed event.
